channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: London's Biggest Perl team
item.description: Large, dynamic Perl team in Canary Wharf looking for mid-level and senior developers. Run by a Perl-loving CTO in beautiful offices with a great view over Canary Wharf, the company manages one legacy Perl codebase and a whole bunch of very new, very shiny, and very modern codebases

item.title: Problem-solvers for very strong Perl Fintech/Banking team in London
item.description: Very strong Perl team in central London with a reputation for technical excellence and doing things their own way. Expect to be challenged by very bright co-workers who are determined to move fast and break things.

item.title: Fancy a few days a week in beautiful Irvine, CA? Mountain and harbour views from the office
item.description: We are looking for a fulltime Perl developer who can join us onsite at our beautiful offices a few days a week in Irvine, and work from home the rest of the time (or fulltime in Irvine).

item.title: Perl 5 Core Hackathon (p5hack) Report
item.description: This was the first Perl 5 Core Hackathon in Amsterdam.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Your own template engine in 4 flavors. With Benchmarks!
item.description: The rite of passage for real Perl developers was to build a templating engine. Now you can see how to do that in Perl 6.

item.title: 2017.08 Evolving Slangs
item.description: The Perl 6 Weekly with link collection.

item.title: Import on demand
item.description: Anotother entry published from the the Advanced Perl videos series that was earlier only available to paying members of the Perl Maven site.

item.title: Perl 5 Porters Mailing List Summary: February 13th-19th
item.description: Lots of grant reports and a number of issues handled.

item.title: Maintaining Perl 5: Grant Report for January 2017
Configuring NGINX for SSL with Letâ€™s Encrypt
item.description: Mojolicious has some built-in magic to do this.

item.title: Testing my tests
item.description: This is a question: Is there some tool for Perl that would randomly change the AUT and run the tests effectively trying to figure out if the tests would catch those changes?

item.title: Machine learning in Perl
item.description: 'So I had a sad day around Dec 15 and decided to try to repay Perl for 19 years of taking care of me.' ++ for that!

item.title: Always use warnings in your Perl code!
item.description: In almost every place where Perl is written by people who are not connected to the Open Source Perl community, they still need to be convinced of the advantages of 'use warnings'. Here you can find a number of examples of what could go wrong if you did not have 'use warnings' in your code.

item.title: Callback Functions Between C and Perl
item.description: Everything you ever want to do with xs is documented somewhere in perlxs, perlguts, perlapi, perlxstypemap, and perlcall. Figuring out where it's documented, and how it relates to everything else, is the hard part.

item.title: Perl and Redis
item.description: Redis is one of the mainstream NoSQL databases. Mihai provides some basic information on how to use it from Perl.

item.title: #292 - Always use warnings
item.description:
Hi there

there are several good articles this week and I also have a few of mine.

Enjoy your week and if you have any news you'd like to share with the readers of the Perl Weekly, let us know!
item.dc:subject: list of tags?
